\begin{abstract}

The electrons in Graphene Nano Ribbons (GNRs) experience strong electron-electron interactions. 
Most theoretical models developed are based on either single-band tight-binding model or
restricted configuration interactions which cannot capture the role of correlations adequately.
The GNRs are quasi-one-dimensional systems and narrow GNRs can be studied using the highly
accurate density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) method. We have employed the symmetrized
DMRG method to obtain properties such as low-lying one- and two-photon excitations, spin in the
ground state, charge gaps and bond orders. We note that in the zigzag fused naphthalene, the
ground state spin shows a tendency to increase with system size and the system can be expected
to have bulk magnetization in the thermodynamic limit. The two photon gap vanishes in this system
in the thermodynamic limit. The armchair fused naphthalene does not show this behavior and neither
does polyperylene. Armchair fused naphthalene shows very small gap between the one- and two-photon
states and the ordering of the excited states indicates the possibility of strong fluorescence in
this system. Bond order studies show that zigzag fused naphthalene does not have tendency to distort
while armchair fused naphthalene and polyperylene have a tendency to distort along the edges. The
charge gaps indicate that all these systems are semiconducting contrary to the tight-binding calculation 
predictions.

\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}

Carbon has come to the fore in the last few decades for many exciting electronic and magnetic 
properties with the discovery of bucky ball in the eighties to carbon nanotubes in the nineties
to graphene and graphene nanoribbons in the last decade \cite{saito, dresselhaus, geim}. In all these
systems, we can notionally assume that the carbon atom is in sp$^2$ hybridization. Hence,
these systems belong to the class of conjugated carbon systems. In recent years, Graphene nanoribbons 
(GNRs) have attracted huge attention because of their exotic electronic properties and plausible 
applications in nanoelectronics \cite{neto, allen, sarma, Schwierz, morris}. GNRs are quasi one-dimensional 
forms of graphene, which exhibit exciting electronic properties because of the confinement of electrons 
in low dimension \cite{neto, fujita, nakada, ezawa, Wakabayashi}. These electronic properties also depend  
crucially on the geometry of the edges of the infinite ribbons. The GNRs are classified into two types based 
on the edge structures, namely, zigzag and armchair GNRs. Based on the one-band tight-binding approximation, 
it is found that the band gap of zigzag GNRs is zero and the ground state is metallic while the band gap of 
armchair GNRs varies from insulating to semiconducting or metallic as a function of the ribbon width 
\cite{ezawa, brey, son}. Ribbons with 3p+2 (p is an integer) dimer bonds (bonds between neighboring sites 
along the ribbon width) in a unit cell are metallic and others are semiconducting \cite{son}. GNRs with 
different widths have been made using various techniques like mechanical cutting of exfoliated graphenes or by
patterning epitaxially grown graphenes \cite{berger, chen, han, tapaszto, datta1, li}.

\begin{center} 
\includegraphics[width=8.0cm]{struc_ribbons.eps}
\caption{\label{strucr} Molecular structures of (a) zigzag fused naphthalene (b) armchair 
fused naphthalene and (c) polyperylene. The unit cell for each nanoribbon is shown within 
square brackets.}
\end{center}

Because the GNRs are made of sp$^2$ carbon atoms and are quasi one-dimensional,
the $\pi$-electrons in GNRs experience strong electron repulsions. Besides, in these systems,
it is reasonable to expect long-range electron-electron interactions as the armchair GNRs
are semiconducting and even in metallic GNRs, the screening length for electron-electron
interactions can be expected to be long as these systems are better described as zero
gap semiconductors. Thus, understanding the electronic properties such as optical gaps, 
two-photon gaps, charge gaps and related properties of GNRs requires an accurate study 
of long-range correlated models. For conjugated carbon systems, it has been well established 
that the excited state properties are well reproduced by the Pariser-Parr-Pople (PPP) model which
assumes $\sigma - \pi$ separability and incorporates long-range electron-electron repulsions \cite{pppm,*pople}. 
The GNRs being quasi-one-dimensional, the symmetrized density matrix renormalization group 
(DMRG) method provides highly accurate description of ground and low-lying excited states. 
In this work, we have studied the electronic properties of a few of the following 
nanoribbons: 1) zigzag fused naphthalene in which naphthalene units are fused to form a zigzag GNR 
structure, 2) an armchair fused naphthalene and 3) fused perylenes in armchair configuration 
by employing the DMRG method within the PPP model. We have also studied the spin and charge gaps in the 
presence of long-range electron-electron interactions. We have also computed the bond orders 
to examine the tendency of these systems for Peierls type distortion. 
 
There are some related works on the zigzag and armchair GNRs which we briefly mention here. 
Fujita et al. have studied both armchair and zigzag graphene ribbons with tight
binding approximation and reported the presence of edge states near the Fermi level for zigzag
nanoribbons, resulting in high density of states near the Fermi level \cite{fujita}. The wave vectors of edge state
wavefunctions, $k$, satisfy $2\pi/3\le|k|\le\pi$. These states are highly localized at the edge sites and small
penetration from the edge sites towards inner sites are observed when $|k|<\pi$ but are completely localized for $k=\pi$. 
Presence of these almost flat bands is absent in armchair nanoribbons and is a consequence of the topology of the 
$\pi$-electronic structure. The flattening of these bands increases for wider ribbons although 
the overall importance of these states in the band structure diminishes. However, even in a general 
nanoribbon which cannot be classified either as perfectly armchair or perfectly zigzag, a few sequentially 
placed zigzag sites can result in significant density of states at the Fermi level \cite{nakada}. 
In the correlated picture, these almost flat bands result in magnetic solutions where spins are arranged 
ferromagnetically at the edges \cite{fujita}. Because of the degeneracy of these half-filled orbitals, 
the direct exchange interactions between the electrons occupying these orbitals lead to a ferromagnetic state.
Opposite edges of the ribbon will have opposite alignment of spins making the ribbon non-magnetic in the thermodynamic 
limit. Ezawa has studied bandgaps in a range of nanoribbons in the H\"{u}ckel picture and predicted the width 
dependence of the bandgaps in these systems \cite{ezawa}. He has also found incorporation of edge effects by 
changing the transfer term or site energies of the edge sites has little effect on the band structure. 
Brey and Fertig studied electronic structure of zigzag and armchair nanoribbons using massless Dirac 
equation and their results are in agreement with the tight binding results, except for narrow nanoribbons \cite{brey}.
They proposed that the continuum analysis of graphene can quantitatively predict the properties of these systems. 
Son et al. have computed the band gaps for armchair GNRs using the first-principle 
approach \cite{son}. They have also confirmed that the geometry of edges plays an important role in determining 
if the band gap is vanishing or non-vanishing. The edge magnetism in zigzag nanoribbon has also been 
studied using mean-field Hubbard model by Jung and coworkers \cite{jung}, employing quantum Monte Carlo 
technique by Golor et al. \cite{golor} and by renormalization technique by Hikihara et al. \cite{hikihara} 
and experimentally observed at room temperature by Magda and coworkers \cite{magda}. Using quantum 
many-body configuration interaction method, Dutta $et~al.$ have studied low-energy properties 
such as the ground state energies as well as the ground state spins, spin and charge densities 
of both zigzag and armchair GNRs within the Hubbard model \cite{datta2}. They have predicted 
that the ground state of zigzag GNR is a high-spin state and for armchair GNR the ground 
state is a singlet. Within the PPP model, the spin and charge gaps of the armchair polyacene 
have been studied by Das \cite{das}. She has shown that the ground state of armchair polyacene 
is a singlet and she predicted that this system is an insulator in the ground state. 
 

This paper is organized as follows. In section II, we introduce the model Hamiltonian  
and briefly describe the numerical technique which we have employed in our study. In section III, 
we present and discuss the results of zigzag and armchair fused naphthalenes and polyperylene.  
In the final section, we present a comparison of these three systems and summarize our results. 

\section{Model Hamiltonian for Graphene Nanoribbons}

We have employed the PPP Hamiltonian to study the electronic properties of these nanoribbons.

where the intersite repulsion integrals, $V_{ij}$-s are interpolated between U at $r_{ij}=0$ {\AA} and 
$e^2/r_{ij}$ for $r_{ij}\rightarrow$ $\infty$. For our study, we have taken the nearest neighbor distance 
between the carbon atoms as 1.42 {\AA} and we fixed parameters, $t_{ij}$ as $-2.40$ eV and U as $11.26$ eV. 

We are interested in the properties of the zigzag and armchair fused naphthalenes and polyperylene systems 
(Fig. \ref{strucr}) in the thermodynamic limit. Thus, to achieve the thermodynamic limit, we need to resort 
to the finite size scaling technique. Exact studies of the model Hamiltonian is confined, at best, to about 
18 carbon sites and hence cannot be employed for extrapolation to the thermodynamic limit. Restricted configuration 
interaction approaches are not size consistent and hence cannot be employed with finite size scaling. Quantum Monte 
Carlo approach is also not suitable since we have long-range interactions in the model. However, the systems 
studied are quasi one-dimensional and DMRG method appears to be best suited for this study. The DMRG method is 
known to be very accurate for one-dimensional systems far from criticality. The area law guarantees that for 
the same level of approximation, similar accuracy is retained independent of system size \cite{scholl,hall}.
It has also been shown that for models with diagonal interactions in the real space such as the PPP model, 
the entanglement entropy is similar to those in the Hubbard and the Heisenberg models in one-dimension 
\cite{durga}. Thus, we can treat a system described by the PPP model Hamiltonian as a quasi-one-dimensional 
system, within a DMRG approach. Hence, we have employed the DMRG method to carry out our studies on these systems.

The DMRG method invented by White in 1992 divides a system block into two sub-blocks
\cite{white,*white-prb}. Density matrix of a chosen sub-block is obtained by treating the other
block as an environment block and tracing the density over the states of the environment block.
The density matrix eigenvectors (DMEVs) are chosen to span the Fock space of the sub-block. 
The Fock space is truncated by retaining a subset of the DMEVs which have the highest densities.
The next step in the DMRG algorithm involves expanding the system block by adding a few sites (usually two) 
to the previous system block. The Hamiltonian matrix is constructed in the basis of the retained DMEVs
and Fock states of the newly added sites. From the Hamiltonian matrix, desired eigenstates
are obtained and the process of constructing the density matrix, truncating the Fock space of
the augmented system and expanding the system by adding two additional sites and solving for 
the desired eigenstate of the system is repeated until we achieve the desired system size.
The dimension of the Hamiltonian matrix is independent of the system size as the number of DMEVs 
retained to span the Fock space of the sub-blocks is fixed, independent of the size of the sub-block.
The method described above is the infinite DMRG method.

To improve the accuracy for a finite system, White further developed a method called the finite DMRG method. 
In the infinite DMRG method, the density
matrix of a p-site sub block is built from the eigenstates of a 2p site system block. This leads to
errors in the target system of 2N sites ($N>>p$). In order to correct this error, the
p-site density matrices are iteratively constructed from the eigenstates of the 2N site
target system block, until convergence is achieved. The finite DMRG procedure for molecular systems is 
nontrivial but essential as the energies improve considerably following the sweeping. We have employed 
the finite DMRG algorithm with a DMEV cut-off {\it m}, of 500 and finite DMRG iteration of two sweeps
to compare the DMRG method results with the exact calculation results for zigzag and armchair 
fused naphthalene structures as well as for the polyperylene within the non-interacting model (Table \ref{tab_huckel}).
The ground state energies compare well with the exact H\"uckel energies in all cases for 
the DMEV cut-off at m=500.  For the interacting models, we expect the DMRG 
method to be more accurate for the same cut-off as interacting systems are less entangled. 
The method of constructing the GNRs in the infinite DMRG procedure as well as 
the method of finite sweeps is shown in Fig. \ref{dmrg_zigzag} and Figs. $1$, $2$ and $3$ in the supplemental material 
\cite{supple}.

The Hamiltonian has both total spin conservation and electron-hole symmetry. While exploiting
total spin conservation is difficult within the DMRG scheme, we can exploit partial spin
symmetry by confining to the $M_S=0$ sector in which the Hamiltonian has spin inversion 
symmetry. This symmetry corresponds to invariance of the Hamiltonian when all spins of the
system are flipped. This symmetry bifurcates the $M_S=0$ space into a space with even total spin, i.e., 
$S = 0, 2, 4,\cdot\cdot\cdot$ and another with odd total spin, $S=1, 3, 5,\cdot\cdot\cdot$.
All these systems also have $C_2$ symmetry along the axis perpendicular to the plane of 
the molecule. The identity, these three symmetry operators and their products form an Abelian group
of eight elements. Hence, the $M_S=0$ 
sector gets subdivided into 8 subspaces. In general the ground state and the two-photon states 
of conjugated systems lie in `${}^eA^+$' subspace, while the dipole allowed, one-photon state 
(optical state) lies in the `${}^eB^-$' subspace. In $M_S=1$ sector, spin inversion symmetry cannot be
employed and the lowest triplet state remains in `$B^+$' space. The `$+$' and `$-$' superscript on the 
right-hand side denotes the character under electron-hole symmetry operation while `e' and `o' superscripts on the
left hand side indicate the character under spin inversion symmetry. Using symmetrized DMRG method \cite{pati} 
with a modified algorithm \cite{suryo}, all of these symmetries have been exploited in these calculations.
In symmetrized DMRG calculations, we have kept the DMRG cut-off $m \sim 750-800$. 

\section{Results and Discussion}

\subsection*{Ground state energy per unit cell}

\begin{figure}[tpb]
\begin{center} 
\includegraphics[width=8.5cm,height=7.5cm]{ebyn_1.eps}
\caption{\label{ebyn} Ground state energy per unit cell vs 1/N for (a) zigzag and (b) armchair fused naphthalene 
and (c) polyperylene systems within the PPP model where N is the number of unit cells as depicted in Fig. \ref{strucr}.} 
\end{center} 
\end{figure}

We have used the unsymmetrized DMRG technique to calculate the ground state energies of these systems within the PPP 
model (Fig. \ref{ebyn}). The excellent linear fit of the energies as a function of system size shows that 
the procedure is stable and accurate. For comparison, the ground state energy per site in polyacetylene is -2.14 eV, 
while the same are -2.556 eV, -2.625 eV and -2.571 eV in case of zigzag and armchair fused naphthalenes and polyperylene 
systems. This also shows that the aromatic stabilization of armchair fused naphthalene is the highest, followed by 
polyperylene and zigzag fused naphthalene which are all comparable and have greater resonance stabilization than 
carbon atoms in polyene \cite{kuwajima}. In the thermodynamic limit, the ground state energies per unit cell of zigzag 
and armchair fused naphthalenes extrapolate to -15.34 eV and -31.50 eV respectively while in polyperylene it extrapolates 
to -25.71 eV per unit cell.

\subsection*{Spin gaps}

In the DMRG scheme, it is difficult to exploit total spin invariance. Thus, we can only obtain the total $M_S$ value 
of a state and not the total spin. However, it is possible to determine the spin of a state in the $M_S=0$ sector by 
computing the lowest energy states in different $M_S$ sectors. Hence, we have computed the lowest energy states of these 
systems in different sectors and obtained the energy gaps ($\Delta_k$) defined as $\Delta_k=E_0(M_S=k)-E_0(M_S=0)$, where 
the energy $E_0(M_S=k)$ is the lowest energy in the $M_S=k$ sector. If  $\Delta_1\neq 0$, we can conclude that the state 
is a singlet. This is because, if the lowest energy state with $M_S=0$ is nondegenerate and the corresponding energy 
eigenvalue does not appear in the lowest state with $M_S=1,$ then the spin degeneracy of the state is 1 or the state is 
a singlet. In general if $\Delta_1=\Delta_2=\cdot\cdot\cdot=\Delta_p=0$ and $\Delta_{p+1}>0$, we can conclude that the 
ground state has spin $S=p$. This is because the $S=p$ state will have a presence in the $M_S=0,1,2,...,p$ sectors with 
the same energy. Fig. \ref{spingap_ribbons}(a) shows the spin gaps as a function of the inverse of number of naphthalene 
units (N) for zigzag fused naphthalene. For less than 14 units ($N<14$), we find a finite spin gap between $M_S=1$ and $M_S=0$ 
states which indicates that the ground state is a singlet. For $N\geq14$, $M_S=1$ and $M_S=0$ states are degenerate 
(within the DMRG accuracy) which implies that S=1 is the spin of the ground state, as the gap between $M_S=2$ and $M_S=0$ is
still finite. However, the gap between $M_S=2$ and $M_S=0$ states becomes smaller as N is further increased. It appears that 
S=2 will become the spin of the ground state for larger N values. Similarly, the gap between $M_S=3$ and $M_S=0$ states also 
reduces with increasing N. From this behavior of the spin gap, we predict that the ground state of this system is a magnetic 
state in the thermodynamic limit. This is consistent with the earlier studies which reveal ferromagnetic arrangement of spins 
at the edge sites of zigzag nanoribbon \cite{fujita,son,datta2}.

\begin{figure}[tbp]
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=8.5cm]{huckel.eps}
\caption{\label{huckel} A few energy levels near the Fermi level for (a) zigzag fused naphthalene, (b) armchair fused naphthalene and 
(c) polyperylene within the tight-binding model are plotted as a function of number of unit cells. The hopping energy 
considered is 2.40 eV. The symbol index is same for all the three panels and are as follows: HOMO energy level (solid circle); 
HOMO--1 energy level (solid square); HOMO--2 energy level (solid triangle up); LUMO energy level (open circle); LUMO+1 energy 
level (open square) and LUMO+2 energy level (open triangle up).}
\end{center}

The spin gaps for armchair fused naphthalene are shown in Fig. \ref{spingap_ribbons}(b). In the thermodynamic limit, the spin gap 
($\Delta_1$) between $M_S=1$ and $M_S=0$ states is non-zero and it has a weak size dependence. The extrapolated value of spin gap 
($\Delta_1$) in the thermodynamic limit is 1.43 eV which is slightly higher than the spin gap in the non-interacting picture of 1.19 eV.
This implies that the ground state of this system is a singlet. Indeed the spin gap is large compared to polyacene which has a spin gap of 
$\sim$0.5 eV in the thermodynamic limit. The spin gaps between the lowest energy levels in $M_S=2$ and $M_S=3$ sectors and the lowest level 
in $M_S=0$ sector are also large. The lowest energy levels in the $M_S=2$ and $M_S=3$ sectors always lie above the lowest energy level in 
$M_S=1$ sector with increasing number of naphthalene units. This shows that the excitations are of progressively higher energies 
with increasing spin. 

For polyperylene, the spin gaps between different $M_S$ sectors and $M_S=0$ are shown in Fig. \ref{spingap_ribbons}(c).
In the thermodynamic limit, the spin gap ($\Delta_1$) between the lowest states of $M_S=1$ and $M_S=0$ sectors extrapolates 
to 0.15 eV. The spin gap is unusually small and the behavior of $\Delta_2$ and $\Delta_3$ seems to imply that they come close 
to $\Delta_1$. Thus, it appears that in this system even though the ground state is a singlet, the lowest excited spin state may have 
a higher spin ($S>1$). 

Within the non-interacting one-band tight-binding model, we have computed a few energy levels above and below 
the Fermi level for systems up to 50 units of zigzag and armchair fused naphthalenes and polyperylene. 
In the zigzag fused naphthalene and polyperylene systems, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular 
orbital (LUMO) energy levels are nearly degenerate at the Fermi level (Figs. \ref{huckel}(a) and \ref{huckel}(c)). Hence, both the systems 
are metallic in the non-interacting picture. Interaction can lead to both insulating behavior and flat-band magnetism in these systems. 
In armchair fused naphthalene system, the HOMO and LUMO energy levels are well separated at the Fermi level (Fig. \ref{huckel}(b)). 
Hence, this system is not a candidate for exhibiting flat-band magnetism.

\subsection*{Lowest two-photon gap and optical gap}

\begin{figure}[btp]
\begin{center} 
\includegraphics[width=8.5cm,height=7.5cm]{tpg_opg.eps}
\caption{\label{tpg_opg} (Color online) Lowest two-photon and optical gaps in (a) armchair fused naphthalene and (b) polyperylene 
are plotted as a function of the inverse of number of unit cells as outlined in Fig. \ref{strucr}. The ground state remains 
in both the cases in $S=0$ space. Color indices are same in both the figures and are as follows: lowest 
two-photon gap ($\square$); lowest optical gap ({\color{Red}$\vartriangle$}). The extrapolated values of the two-
photon gaps and optical gaps are also indicated in the figures.}
\end{center}

We have obtained the low-lying excited states, namely, the one-photon and two-photon states for the above mentioned 
nanoribbons within the PPP model. We have done calculations starting from 2 units up to a maximum of 16 units of zigzag 
fused naphthalene, from 2 units up to a maximum of 8 units of armchair fused naphthalene (with an addition of 2 naphthalene 
rings per cycle) and from 1 unit up to 9 units of polyperylene, which is about 100 carbon atoms in all largest systems studied. 
For zigzag fused naphthalene systems, with size up to three units, lowest two-photon state lies above the lowest optical state, 
but falls below for larger system sizes (Fig. \ref{zigzag_opg}). As already pointed out that the spin of the ground state changes 
beyond a certain size of the nanoribbon, we have plotted in Fig. \ref{zigzag_opg}, the lowest two-photon gaps and lowest optical 
gaps corresponding for both $S=0$ and $S=1$ ground states. In the thermodynamic limit, the two-photon gaps in both singlet and 
triplet spaces extrapolate to zero, small deviation in Fig. \ref{zigzag_opg} corresponding to DMRG and finite size extrapolation 
error. The extrapolated value of the optical gap in thermodynamic limit is found to be 2.25 eV, irrespective of the ground state 
spin. For systems with triplet ground state, the singlet optical gap increases with system size. In armchair fused naphthalene, 
the lowest optical state always remains below the lowest two-photon state for all system sizes. Although the separation is very
small in some systems studied, the extrapolated value at the thermodynamic limit are quite distinct (Fig \ref{tpg_opg}a).
The extrapolated value of the two-photon gap is $2.72$ eV while that of the optical gap is $2.45$ eV. In case of polyperylene, 
the optical state always remains above the lowest two-photon state, although the lowest two-photon gap does not vanish at the 
thermodynamic limit (Fig \ref{tpg_opg}b) but saturates at a value of $0.60$ eV. The optical gap in polyperylene, on the other hand,
extrapolates to 1.33 eV at the thermodynamic limit. The position of the optical state in armchair fused naphthalene below the 
two-photon state can make the system fluorescent in the thermodynamic limit.

We have calculated the charge gaps in these systems to explore the conducting nature in the 
thermodynamic limit, in the presence of long-range interactions (Fig. \ref{chrgegap}). 
The charge gap ($\Delta_c$) is defined as the energy required to create a well separated 
electron-hole pair from the ground state of the system:  $\Delta_c (N) =E^+(N)+E^-(N)-2E^0(N)$, 
where $E^+$ and $E^-$ are the ground state energies of the cation and anion respectively and 
$E^0$ is the ground state energy of the neutral system and $N$ is the system size. 
In the thermodynamic limit, the charge gaps of zigzag and armchair fused naphthalenes and polyperylene 
systems extrapolate to 3.09 eV, 3.58 eV and 2.46 eV. This clearly shows that interactions lead to 
semiconducting behavior in these systems. Interestingly, the exciton binding energy ($E_{xb}$) of 
the optical state ($E_{1ph}$) which is measured as $E_{xb}=E_{cg}-E_{1ph}$ is quite small in 
all the three systems compared to other known organic conjugated systems. The exciton binding energies 
are 0.84 eV in zigzag fused naphthalene, 1.13 eV in armchair fused naphthalene and 1.13 eV in polyperylene 
nanoribbon. Hence, these conjugated systems can have importance in molecular photovoltaics as the 
electron-hole pair can be relatively easily disassociated.

\subsection*{Bond order}

We have calculated bond orders for the ground state and a few low-lying excited states
of the largest systems we studied. Bond order ($p_{ij}$) for the $<i,j>$ bond is defined as  
$(-\frac{1}{2}) \sum_{\sigma}(a_{i\sigma}^\dagger a_{j\sigma}+h.c.)$, and their deviation 
from an average value shows propensity for the bond to distort. If the bond order is more (less) 
than the average, we expect the bond to shorten (lengthen) at equilibrium geometry. 
The numbering of bonds of the interior zigzag and armchair fused naphthalenes and perylene units 
is shown in Fig. \ref{bndindx}. The bond orders towards the ends of the ribbons are 
normally different from the bond orders in the interior part because of edge effects. 
In Table \ref{tab_bndord1}, the bond orders of the interior unit of zigzag fused naphthalene 
are given. In zigzag fused naphthalene series, we have given bond orders for two systems, 
one with 13 monomer units, which has a singlet ground state and another one with 16 monomer units 
with triplet ground state. In both systems, the bond order difference between edge bonds in the ground 
state are small, implying almost uniform geometry of the edges. The rung bond orders are bit smaller 
than the edge bonds, implying longer rung bonds than edge bonds at equilibrium geometry. The ground state,
optical state and the lowest spin state all have similar geometries. The bond orders in the singlet and
triplet two-photon states are similar away from middle of the ribbon. However, in the middle of the ribbon,
the triplet two-photon state has marked single and double bond character in the top and bottom edge bonds
(bonds 1, 2, 10, 11).

The bond orders in fused armchair naphthalene show somewhat different behavior. In the ground state, bonds on 
the ring and on the exterior of the edge (bond 13) show propensity to contract, while bond 3 on the edge which 
is on the interior shows a tendency to expand. There appears to be a period of four distortion of the edges 
typified by {short-short-short-long} on one edge and out of phase by two bonds on the opposite edge. 
In two-photon state, the bond orders remain almost same as those in the ground state, only the 
overall structure gets a little weaker. In one-photon state, there is considerable deviation in the 
bond orders at the middle part of the nanoribbon, but the effect reduces on moving towards the 
ends. However in the triplet state it appears that this distortion is much more pronounced. Thus, 
the equilibrium geometries of the excited states are quite different from that in the ground state 
and we may expect larger Stokes shifts in the spectra of the armchair fused naphthalene compared to the 
zigzag fused naphthalene. 

The bond orders on the edges of polyperylene are similar to the bond orders in the 
armchair fused naphthalene. Except for the bonds which have rather large and small bond order values, 
all other bonds have nearly the same bond orders. So the distortion is expected more on the edges than 
the interior. In all excited states, the interior bonds remain almost unperturbed. The edge bond 
structure at the middle part of the nanoribbon shifts from short-long-short-short type to 
long-long-long-short type structure, while being unchanged towards the ends of the nanoribbon. 
The extent of distortion at the middle part is highest in the two-photon and triplet states as compared 
to one-photon state.

\section{Conclusion}

We have studied correlated electronic properties of zigzag and armchair fused naphthalenes 
and of polyperylene systems in the presence of long-range electron-electron interactions. 
We have studied the ground state, the lowest triplet state, the lowest one-photon and two-photon
states in members of each series and extrapolated their nature to the thermodynamic limit. The spin gap 
studies show that the zigzag fused naphthalene, in the thermodynamic limit will have a high spin ground 
state. The ground state of armchair fused naphthalene is a singlet and variation in the spin gap of 
this system is independent of the system size. In polyperylene, the spin gap is small in the 
thermodynamic limit. 

We have also computed optical and two-photon gaps of these systems. In the case of zigzag fused naphthalene, 
the two-photon gap is very small while in armchair fused naphthalene, the two-photon and one-photon gaps 
are comparable. In armchair fused naphthalene in the thermodynamic limit the two-photon state is above the 
one-photon state and we expect the system to be fluorescent. Bond order studies of these systems have 
shown that armchair fused naphthalene and polyperylene systems are likely to show Peierls type of instability 
along the edges, with a periodicity of four bonds. It has also revealed that there is considerable change in 
the excited state molecular structure from the ground state, though the variation is highest at the middle 
part of the ribbon. We have also calculated charge gaps of these systems where all three systems show 
similar charge gaps in the thermodynamic limit.
